facts.text: The Co-operative Societies held their annual general meeting under section 32 of the Uttar Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act, 1965 and elected members of the Committee of Management.

anchor.surface_text: These Co-operative Societies held their annual general meeting under the provisions of section 32 of the Uttar Pradesh Co-operative Societies Act, 1965  hereinafter called the Act . At the general meetings the members of the Committee of Management of the Society were elected by members of the Society.

facts.text: The Registrar of the U.P. Co-operative Societies issued a circular dated 5 November, 1969 interpreting rule 409 of the U.P. Co-operative Societies Rules, 1968 laying down that all members of the general body would exercise their right of vote in filling all the seats of elected Directors.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of the U.P. Co-operative Societies issued a circular dated 5 November, 1969 interpreting rule 409 of the P. Co-operative Societies Rules, 1968  hereinafter called the Rules  and laid down the principle that all the members of the general body of the Co-operative Society would exercise their right of vote in filling all the seats of elected Directors.

facts.text: The Shamli Cane Development Union Ltd., Shamli, U.P. was registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912 and deemed to be registered under the U.P. Co-operative Societies Act, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: The Shamli Cane Development Union Ltd., Shammli, U.P. was registered under the Co-operative Societies Act, 1912. It was deemed to be registered under the Act.

facts.text: The Shamli society had bye-laws providing for a committee of management consisting of 14 members divided into 14 constituencies, each electing one Director.

anchor.surface_text: The society had its bye-laws with regard to the formation of the companymittee of management and its election including the election of the Chairman and the Vice-Chairman. The bye-laws provided for a companymittee of management companysisting of 14 members. The companymittee of management elects a Chairman and a Vice- Chairman. The delegates companystituting the general body of the society are divided into 14 companystituencies. Each companystituency elects one Director.

facts.text: The Secretary of the Shamli society fixed 13 October, 1970 as the date for filing nomination for the office of the committee of management.

anchor.surface_text: The Secretary of the society fixed 13 October, 1970 as the date for filing the numberination for the office of the companymittee of management.

facts.text: 17 October, 1970 was the date for scrutiny of nomination papers in Shamli society election.

anchor.surface_text: 17 October, 1970 was the date for scrutiny of numberination papers.

facts.text: 19 October, 1970 was the date for withdrawal of nomination papers in Shamli society election.

anchor.surface_text: 19 October, 1970 was the date for withdrawal of numberination papers.

facts.text: 28 October, 1970 was the date of poll in Shamli society election.

anchor.surface_text: 28 October, 1970 was the date of poll.

facts.text: By a letter dated 14 October, 1970 the Registrar, Cooperative Societies directed that the election of the members of the managing committee shall be done by all the representatives of the area of the society and not by the representatives of the related constituencies alone.

anchor.surface_text: By a letter dated 14 October, 1970 the Registrar, Cooperative Societies directed that the election of the members of the managing companymittee shall be done by all the representatives of the area of the society and number by the representatives of the related companystituencies alone.

facts.text: The Registrar's direction meant that every representative shall have as many votes as the members to be elected (14 votes).

anchor.surface_text: This means that every representative -L864Sup.CT/72 shall have as many votes as the members are to be elected. In short, the Registrars interpretation of rule 409 as well as the letter stated that each delegate would vote for 14 members of the companymittee of management and thus each delegate would exercise 14 votes.

facts.text: Elections were held following the circular of the Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the elections which were held following the circular of the Registrar are bad.

facts.text: The three appeals fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the three appeals fail and are dismissed.

facts.text: The two special leave petitions are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The two special leave petitions are also dismissed.

facts.text: Annual general meeting is held once in a co-operative year commencing July 1 and ending June 30.

anchor.surface_text: Section 32 of the Act speaks of annual general meeting which shall be held once in a companyoperative year. A companyoperative year means the year companymencing the first day of July and ending on the 30th June of next following.

facts.text: The Registrar has no power to interpret rule 409.

anchor.surface_text: As to the power of the Registrar to interpret rule 409 it win appear that the rule does number companyfer any power on the Registrar to interpret or to express views to guide the rights of members to vote at the annual general meeting for the purposes of election of the companymittee of management.

facts.text: The impeached circular of the Registrar is illegal and unwarranted.

anchor.surface_text: The impeached circular of the Registrar is illegal and unwarranted Registrar has numberpower to interpret rule 409.

holdings.text: The Registrar has no power to interpret rule 409 or to express views to guide the rights of members to vote at the annual general meeting for the purposes of election of the committee of management.

anchor.surface_text: As to the power of the Registrar to interpret rule 409 it win appear that the rule does number companyfer any power on the Registrar to interpret or to express views to guide the rights of members to vote at the annual general meeting for the purposes of election of the companymittee of management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 409 textually does not confer interpretive power on Registrar; power limited to sanctioning society's divisions.

holdings.text: Under rule 409 the Co-operative Society may with the previous sanction of the Registrar divide its membership into different groups on territorial or any other rational basis and specify the number or proportion of the members of the committee of management for suitable representation.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytrary, under rule 409 the Co-operative Society may with the previous sanction of the Registrar  i  divide its membership into different groups on territorial or any other rational basis and  ii  also specify the number or proportion of the members of the companymittee of management in such a manner that different areas or interests, as the case may be, in the society may, as far as may be, get suitable representation on the companymittee or management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of rule 409 empowers society to divide members and apportion seats for representation, not universal voting.

holdings.text: The right of vote for election of a member of the committee of management is confined to the delegates of the members of that particular constituency.

anchor.surface_text: The rival companytentions which fall for determination are whether the right of vote for election of a member of the companymittee of management is companyfined to the delegates of the members of that particular companystituency or whether a delegate would have the right to vote for all the companystituencies companystituting the companymittee of management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plural voting enlarges electorate beyond constituency, denies local representation, and violates purpose of rule 409 and section 20.

holdings.text: Section 20 provides that a member shall have one vote in the affairs of the society, not as many votes as members of the committee of management.

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellants that section 20 of the Act speaks of a member of the companyoperative society having one vote in the affairs of the society with the result that each member is entitled to exercise as many votes as the members of the companymittee of management.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overlooks explicit 'one vote'; multiple votes violate equality principle irrespective of capital interest.

holdings.text: Rule 105 relates to voting at committee meetings by majority, not to elections of the committee of management.

anchor.surface_text: Some reliance was placed by companynsel for the appellants on rule 105 in support of the companytention that every member would have one vote for each member of the companymittee of management. Rule 105 occurs in Chapter VII relating to meetings and speaks of matters before a companymittee being decided by a majority of votes of the members present.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Context of rule 105 is committee resolutions, not election process.

holdings.text: The impeached circular of the Registrar is illegal and unwarranted as the Registrar has no power to interpret rule 409 or give members more than one vote.

anchor.surface_text: The impeached circular of the Registrar is illegal and unwarranted Registrar has numberpower to interpret rule 409.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circular directs plural voting contrary to rule 409, section 20, and lack of interpretive authority.

holdings.text: Elections held following the circular of the Registrar are bad.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the elections which were held following the circular of the Registrar are bad.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Elections violated statutory voting rights under sections 20, 29, 32 and rule 409.

holdings.text: The rules and the bye-laws cannot be in derogation of the statute and statutory rules.

anchor.surface_text: The rules and the bye-laws cannot be in derogation of the statute and statutory rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subordinate rules must conform to Act; cannot override one member one vote principle.

anchor.surface_text: As to the power of the Registrar to interpret rule 409 it win appear that the rule does number companyfer any power on the Registrar to interpret or to express views to guide the rights of members to vote at the annual general meeting for the purposes of election of the companymittee of management.

anchor.surface_text: On the companytrary, under rule 409 the Co-operative Society may with the previous sanction of the Registrar  i  divide its membership into different groups on territorial or any other rational basis and  ii  also specify the number or proportion of the members of the companymittee of management in such a manner that different areas or interests, as the case may be, in the society may, as far as may be, get suitable representation on the companymittee or management.
For these reasons the three appeals fail and are dismissed. The two special leave petitions are also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The rival companytentions which fall for determination are whether the right of vote for election of a member of the companymittee of management is companyfined to the delegates of the members of that particular companystituency or whether a delegate would have the right to vote for all the companystituencies companystituting the companymittee of management.
For these reasons the three appeals fail and are dismissed. The two special leave petitions are also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: It was said on behalf of the appellants that section 20 of the Act speaks of a member of the companyoperative society having one vote in the affairs of the society with the result that each member is entitled to exercise as many votes as the members of the companymittee of management.
For these reasons the three appeals fail and are dismissed. The two special leave petitions are also dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Some reliance was placed by companynsel for the appellants on rule 105 in support of the companytention that every member would have one vote for each member of the companymittee of management. Rule 105 occurs in Chapter VII relating to meetings and speaks of matters before a companymittee being decided by a majority of votes of the members present.
For these reasons the three appeals fail and are dismissed. The two special leave petitions are also dismissed.
